qas.question: What political ideology dominated Austrian politics in the decades before the second world war?
What key event in 1938 pushed Popper into exile from Austria?
What political ideology do Popper's major works defend?
What form of political organization do Popper's works mainly critique?

answers.text: the annexation of Austria by the German Reich

qas.question: What prevented fascism from taking over Austrian politics?
In what years was fascism prevented from taking over?
What forced Popper to come out of exile?
What was one of Popper's least important works?
Whose books critiqued democratic liberalism as a social and political philosophy?

context: The failure of <b5_0>democratic parties<b5_0/> to prevent <a0_0>fascism<a0_0/> from taking over Austrian politics in the <b6_0>1920s and 1930s<b6_0/> traumatised <b9_0>Popper<b9_0/>. He suffered from the direct consequences of this failure, since <b7_0>events after <a1_0>the Anschluss<b7_0/><a1_0/>, <a4_0>the annexation of Austria by the German Reich<a4_0/> in 1938, forced him into permanent exile. His most important works in the field of social science—<b8_0>The Poverty of Historicism<b8_0/> (1944) and The Open Society and Its Enemies (1945)—were inspired by his reflection on the events of his time and represented, in a sense, a reaction to the prevalent totalitarian ideologies that then dominated Central European politics. His books defended <a2_0>democratic liberalism<a2_0/> as a social and political philosophy. They also represented extensive critiques of the philosophical presuppositions underpinning all forms of <a3_0>totalitarianism<a3_0/>.
